Singapore and Hong Kong are Asia’s two economic powerhouses and occupy the top two spots on the Economic Freedom Index.
While the country also uses a territorial tax system, Singapore views money earned in or remitted to Singapore by a Singapore corporation as local income, and subject to tax.
However, your first S$100,000 (roughly US$75,000) in profits are tax-exempt for the first three years your Singapore corporation is open for business.
Singapore differs from Hong Kong in that Singapore seems to encourage more of an on-the-ground presence.
I personally believe a Labuan corporation in Malaysia gives a Singapore company a run for its money.

My storyBeginning of my journey:After starting and selling two successful businesses in the United States, I left the country to travel the world.
I had invested a sizable portion of my money in mutual funds and real estate.
On top of this, I had also just taken a huge loss in taxes after selling the businesses.
The feeling of losing the fruits of my labor to something out of my control was quite devastating.
I’ve spent the past 10 years finding solutions to these issues.
